Literature Review: The recent transformation of cellular and molecular tools has revolutionized our understanding of breathing control, revealing the intricate complexity of the neural circuits involved. The brainstem, specifically the preBötC (pre-Bötzinger complex) and the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS), play a crucial role in regulating breathing patterns. The preBötC is a key pacemaker for respiratory rhythm generation, while the NTS acts as a sensor for lung stretch and chemical signals. The Hering-Breuer inflation reflex, which inhibits inspiration when the lungs are fully inflated, is also mediated by the NTS. Furthermore, the involvement of serotonin in regulating breathing patterns has been well-documented. Serotonin receptors, particularly 5-HT2A, are found in the preBötC and are involved in the modulation of respiratory rhythm. The recent development of molecular tools, such as optogenetics and RNA interference, has enabled researchers to selectively manipulate specific neuronal populations and gain a deeper understanding of their functions. This has led to the identification of novel neuronal types involved in breathing control, including the inspiratory neurons in the preBötC and the expiratory neurons in the NTS. These findings have significant implications for our understanding of the multifunctionality of breathing and the development of novel therapeutic strategies for respiratory disorders. In addition, the study of breathing control has also shed light on the complex interactions between breathing and other physiological processes, such as heart rate and blood pressure. The recent transformation of cellular and molecular tools has also enabled researchers to investigate the role of lung sensory neurons in regulating breathing patterns. Lung sensory neurons are responsible for detecting changes in lung stretch and chemical signals, and their activity is essential for the proper regulation of breathing. The recent development of molecular tools has enabled researchers to selectively manipulate specific lung sensory neurons and gain a deeper understanding of their functions. This has led to the identification of novel molecular mechanisms involved in regulating breathing patterns, including the role of nitric oxide in modulating inspiratory drive. Overall, the recent transformation of cellular and molecular tools has greatly advanced our understanding of breathing control and has opened up new avenues for research into the complex interactions between breathing and other physiological processes.
